The only thing I've enjoyed about doing mobile apps is that they are soo small in scope. After doing huge Flex apps with all kinds of growth/scalability problems, it's been uber nice to fall back to simple apps that take weeks to get done vs. months.

I feel weird using Flex mobile when I can do stuff like intercept text messages natively.  That said, I love making unconventional and creative UI with Flash.

That's true.  I feel like a whore admitting I feel more comfortable pimping myself out as an Android dev (native) for mobile right now rather than a Flex mobile programmer for all platforms.

My guess is they beleive that eventually Android devices will get fast enough to support native Flash; aka the same runtime we're used. Since iOS doesn't support runtimes, and the code for that is a TON more work, my guess is they'd rather focus hardcore on making that optimized strictly for iOS.
The whole AppCelerator model is rad as hell for simple things, but considering how easy Android is to get into... I'd probably just use it to deploy to iOS, hah

That's really rewarding to work like 2 months on something, publish, and move onto something else. Less risk, etc. That, and... well, it's hard to design with no damn space, and I like a challenge, so that's nice too
